157622638.review:
Took some time to get to it, because I wasn't a big fan of the look of the game, and I felt like I'd get bored quickly, the interface looked awful, like right-clicking a window to open it, wtf is it MS Paint?

BUT I finally gave it a go, and all those prejudices vanished in 2h, and I got freaking addict.

You just forget about all those weird things as soon as you start understanding the fundamentals of the game, it all makes sense, it's all balanced, and what doesn't make sense to you most likely has a mod to fix it.
The dedication of the developers and of the community is beautiful.

This game is a masterpiece, and I'm a tough guy to satisfy, genuinely. It made me re-discover the love of videogames I lost 15 years ago while binge-playing too much boring and easy game.

This one is hard, and you'll like it hard. Thanks for this game.

162008952.review:
9.5/10 "Actual best zombie survival sandbox simulation hidden behind a clunky UI. (Crazy lore unlocks below!)"

Project Zomboid is one of those titles that will remain in Early Access forever. But it is that way for a reason... It is one of the oldest EA titles (alongside Minecraft, which has since graduated from EA) to still be in development today, started by four people and a dream.

PZ is known for its authentic sandbox experience. If you play with default settings, electricity and water will eventually shut off. Loot across the vast map will run out. To get to the endgame, you must plan for ALL eventualities by setting up rain barrels, farms, and discover renewable resources/methods to sustain yourself... while dealing with the growing zombie threat. NPCs aren't in yet, but vehicles have been delivered and have completely changed the game. I expect NPCs to also make a similar lasting impact (or maybe they end up becoming convenient loot boxes, who knows).

PZ allows you to fully customize your experience. You can set zombies as traditional shamblers, fast movers, etc... Loot can be set to replenish over time. There's A LOT of settings to choose from if you're into that kind of thing. There's even an AI director to keep the pacing just right. No matter what kind of emergent gameplay or roleplaying experience you want to have, PZ will make it possible for you.

PZ has great modding support and a greater modding community, extending the game in every direction. Indie Stone also incorporates some of them into the base game, which is very pragmatic because of the sheer scope it's trying to achieve. Some modders even get hired, which is what Valve does. A powerful move when used correctly. That's not to say that everything is perfect, because mods can just as quickly fall apart when the game inevitably changes.

The biggest drawback is the clunky UI, as the learning curve is frustrating especially when you're being chased by zombies with permadeath enabled. This issue cannot be solved until there is a major overhaul along with good keybindings, but this won't be easy because of the simulation aspect AND there is no point until the game is feature complete. You can play around the bad UI to some extent by re-organizing your inventory and using other tricks to get by... But all of it ALWAYS goes out the window once you're being chased with permadeath on.

Now, let's talk about the troubled development of PZ... Or rather, how Indie Stone has pulled through some of the most difficult setbacks in the indie business. Their sheer resilience cannot be overstated because Indie Stone is not some AAA studio and never has been. It's four ordinary humans starting out with barely any money and only passion.

Before PZ was first released as a tech demo on June 2011 under Patch 0.1.4c, Paypal limited their account permanently, stopping withdrawals for 180 days to protect against chargebacks (otherwise Paypal was liable for refunds). So Indie Stone tried Google Checkout, but Google became suspicious of them selling "donations". There was no "pay what you want" option on Google Checkout at the time, so Indie Stone had used a list of pre-order options where you could also add £5, £10, and £15 donations alongside the base game. This might not sound like a big deal, but Indie Stone had all of their development funds (hereafter referred to as "war chest") tied up in an uncertain state, held hostage by Google AND Paypal. Having most of their war chest (and rent money) locked up in an UNCERTAIN state made PZ's future VERY uncertain. Google also waited a month into the pre-orders before doing this, and there were zero guarantees that Indie Stone would ever see those funds again. Google was obviously contacted (a Herculean feat as there wasn't any reliable way to get a hold of them because they were actively avoiding getting into end-user support), but only gave this vague reply: "We advise buyers to contact sellers directly to resolve any order-related issues." Can you see how screwed Indie Stone was now? It was insane, and their forums were on fire. The situation was solved via legal loopholes, but at the time, it could have been the end of PZ.

Next, PZ was leaked and copies started spreading as the game received attention. Not a bad thing, right? But pirates created an auto-updating version using Indie Stone's cloud-based servers and it always re-downloaded the latest version even if you had it. A massive hole was now burning through their war chest as Indie Stone needed to pay for bandwidth used by each individual download, and end-user pirates were spamming it to check for updates. Indie Stone is the gigachad archetype recommending users to try out their game via piracy before buying it, and until it became an actual roadblock to delivering their product, they had no issues turning a blind eye to it. This was solved swiftly by going full manual and eventually selling PZ through Steam and GOG. Now, you may be thinking... So... What's the problem? There was no such thing as Early Access titles on Steam in 2011, because the Greenlight initiative started in 2012! Any of you guys remember that!? So until then, they had to "deal with it", slowing sales and growth. In 2011, games selling in the EA state wasn't common yet because there weren't any reliable platforms to distribute them.

On October 15, 2011, they experienced a devastating break-in. Chris Simpson and Andy Hodgetts had moved into a new apartment and had personal possessions and their laptops, containing six weeks of code, stolen. This almost broke them AND the player base because the current AND next update no longer existed. What about backups? As I understand it, their ISP (Virgin) hadn't set anything up yet, so they were using mobile Internet to get online for now, which makes regular online backups not feasible. They backed up data across all of their PCs, which is the next best thing. Imagine being a team of four who had finally climbed various hurdles towards success and then getting all of your legs taken out instantly. Again, they're ordinary people like you and I, not some AAA studio. It was their "Great Depression", and sentiments were at an all-time low across the board because it would greatly extend development times while online comments humiliated them.

Despite all of this, and the constant negative feedback, Indie Stone never gave up. It's now 2024, and they're still going strong. Haters often don't realize how small the team was, or they're used to the fast "asset flips" Unreal Engine is capable of. But this is all indie, and the main ingredient is love, and in its current state, I'm ready to write the review while giving you some crazy lore unlocks in the process.

I wouldn't say I'm a PZ loremaster... I'm just a degen gamer who bought it back in Feb 2014. Before then, I pirated this game to try it. I was one of the end-user pirates spamming the update button. I've been there when multiplayer and vehicles were just a promise... So I get it if you don't believe in the game. But I do, and I seriously think this is the best zombie survival sandbox simulation on the market because I was there when it was a mere public tech demo. I've gifted several copies to my friends.

Indie Stone has the special type of resilience that will get them through anything. Their process is slow, but the result is good despite the sheer epic scope they're trying to deliver. Since then, there have been games like DayZ, but PZ is the only one that offers the most authentic zombie survival sandbox simulation experience.

You can watch their presentation on their woes, back when they were still a team of four and not the thirty (or so) today: https://youtu.be/HYgPI0qkdU4 (search: zomboid rezzed how not to make a game)

Highlights:
@ 16:16 - getting around Google Checkout
@ 22:50 - getting burgled

Thanks for reading, this was a long one (but not as long as their development time, amirite?).

159999305.review:
I have played a lot of hours in this game, not exactly all are played as I have left the game running idle for many hours or forgot to close it. I wish Steam tracked "active" hours versus just sitting there paused, but anyway that is a rant for another time.

Here are some of my pros and cons to the game as it currently stands from a long time player:

Pros
Highly Customizable Goals/Objectives
You can make this game be anything you want. If you want to be a survival versus zombies you can do that, if you want it to be survival versus other players you can do that! If you want to RP as a survivor in the PZ world you can do that. The options are endless!!
Realistic Thought/Activities
You can drive vehicles in the game, and while driving you can't craft. Jumping through broken windows can injure you. These are things you should know/expect to happen when performing them and it is a lot of fun to see this implemented.
Mod Support
Countless mods to add whatever you want in the game that doesn't come wrapped with the vanilla product. If you want to fight zombies with a large spoon, guess what, there is a mod for it. There has never been a time that someone has asked "Is this in the game?" and my response, "There is a mod for it" has failed.
Learning Curve Is Steep - Base Game
This game has a massive learning curve, and I thrive on that so it is a personal pro for me, but not everyone wants to do that. But again, it is highly customizable so I find this as just an added feature from the base game having such a learning curve.
Great Price
Very affordable for what it offers and I would challenge any other company to make the same type of game and charge the same amount. I have been a gamer for over 30 years, and I haven't seen it. However, if someone knows one I would love to learn about it.

Cons:
End-Game Is Very Limited
While I mentioned it as a plus that you can have some highly customizable goals/objectives, once those are accomplished the game doesn't offer much. You have to accept that basically there is no end-game/roll credit scenario, the ending is up to you and sometimes the race to complete your goals might not take very long. This is a problem of all survival games in one sense or another, but it is a problem of the genre versus this game in particular I feel.
Critical Bugs/RNG
Some people will experience bugs that will end their game and it isn't their fault. I have seen screenshots and experienced issues where my character just up and died while walking down a set of stairs before. This has happened on MP a lot, some of my friends die from desync issues. This is something the dev team is aware of and working on in regards to MP, but these are problems you could encounter. RNG can also stack against you, you might be looking for supplies and hop into an alarmed building after being injured. You might find a cool weapon right off the bad or not find one for many days making you struggle tremendously. RNG is a major factor in encountering the bugs as well.
Update Roll-Outs
The game is developed by a small team, and so they are slow at making updates. Not everyone has the money to throw around like some big AAA companies, TIS is very much an Indie Company and so they don't have crazy resources so expect slow delays. Some people are impatient, and I can be at times but it is a fact of life you will encounter.

These are my thoughts from a long time player, I love playing this game and I enjoy hearing others having fun with it as well. It is a game that can be really great to play because of the elements and things you can do in it. However, expect some issues that may or may not end your game too early that is not your fault.

162310626.review:
[h1]After 26 days, I felt like an unstoppable force.[/h1] 


My base was a fortress, fortified with armed survivors courtesy of the Superb Survivors Mod. Behind the wheel of my massive van, towing a trailer filled to the brim with loot, weapons, and enough ammo to start a war, I was the king of this post-apocalyptic world. But even kings have room for improvement, and for me, it was learning how to connect generators.

[h2]I cannot hammer in enough how INVINCIBLE I thought I was...[/h2]

I scoured every inch of the nearby town, raiding every store and flipping through every book, desperate to find the elusive magazine that held the key to my upgrade. And just when I thought I'd searched everywhere, I realized my gas supply was dwindling. With the pumps useless without electricity, my gas-guzzling van was devouring fuel faster than I could find it.

Determined to solve both problems, I embarked on an expedition, gathering every last drop of gasoline and stocking up on supplies. Confident in my ability to handle the zombie hordes, I set out into the desolate cities and roads, ready to conquer whatever challenges came my way.

After what felt like days of pitstops and unwelcomed visits to abandoned homes, I stumbled upon a trailer park, a potential treasure trove in this barren wasteland. Excited by the prospect of finding what I needed, I approached an old Survivor's trailer home, hoping it held the magazine I sought. But as I pried off the boarded-up window and dispatched a couple of zombies lurking outside, I was unprepared for what awaited me inside. 

[h2] When I initially peeked In, all I saw were a couple zeds... [/h2]

Instead of the two zombies I expected, I was met with a mini horde, swarming me within the cramped home like hungry vultures. Panic surged through me as they closed in, their grasping hands reaching for me with deadly intent. In a desperate attempt to fend them off, I frantically mashed the space bar, trying to shove them away but with each shove my character strained harder, to exhausted to push any more... it was futile.

As the zombies overwhelmed me, tearing through flesh and bone with savage efficiency, I could only watch in horror as everything I'd worked so hard for was torn apart before my eyes. "This is how you died," is how the game started I didn't expect these words to ring true so soon..

Heartbroken and defeated, I stared at the screen, feeling the weight of my failure. But in that moment of despair, a spark of determination ignited within me. "I won't make that mistake again," I vowed, steeling myself for the challenges that lay ahead.

And with that, I returned to the menu, ready to dive back into the fray (in a new world with a new character of course). Because in this unforgiving world, the only way to survive is to keep pushing forward, learning from your mistakes, and most importantly, knowing when you're in over your head..

160395345.review:
Project Zomboid stands out as an exceptional entry in the survival genre, offering a deep and immersive experience that challenges players to truly think about what it means to survive in a post-apocalyptic world. With its realistic survival mechanics and the ever-present threat of permadeath, each moment in the game is filled with tension and strategic decision-making.

Players commend the game for its customization options, allowing for a tailored zombie apocalypse experience that can be modified with a variety of mods. The community highlights the game’s ability to provide hundreds of hours of engaging gameplay, with one player noting an impressive 700-hour playtime and still going strong1.

The game’s isometric view and role-playing elements add to its charm, creating a unique blend of simulation and storytelling. Whether you’re fortifying your safe house, scavenging for supplies, or fending off a horde of zombies, Project Zomboid consistently delivers a thrill. It’s a game that rewards patience and strategic planning, and for those who enjoy a challenge, it’s an absolute must-play.

With an active development team and a passionate community, Project Zomboid is not just a game—it’s an evolving survival experience that continues to grow and improve. It’s a testament to indie gaming, proving that with the right elements, a game can create a captivating world that players are eager to return to, time and time again.

In conclusion, Project Zomboid is more than worth the investment for fans of the survival genre. It’s a game that will test your limits, push your creativity, and leave you with memorable stories of survival against all odds.

I hope this review captures the essence of what makes Project Zomboid a beloved game among its players. If you’re looking for a survival game that offers depth, complexity, and a strong community, Project Zomboid is definitely worth checking out.

It is true that it does not have the best graphics for the time and that it could have a lot more polished things... but it is unique in creating a zombie movie atmosphere.

- You want to go Rambo style and kill everything that moves: then arm yourself and make noise and let all the zombies come.

162970570.review:
Project Zomboid is a zombie survival game that sets itself apart from the crowded undead horde by offering a deep and realistic simulation of survival in a post-apocalyptic world. Developed by Indie Stone, this game has been in Early Access for years, but it's a shining example of how a committed indie team can create something truly special.

At its core, Project Zomboid is about survival. You'll scavenge for supplies, fortify safehouses, interact with other survivors (if you're lucky), and, of course, fight off hordes of zombies. What sets this game apart is its commitment to realism. You'll need to manage hunger, thirst, exhaustion, and mental health, all while dealing with injuries, illnesses, and the ever-present threat of the undead.

The game's isometric perspective and retro-style graphics might seem simplistic at first glance, but don't be fooled—this is a game with surprising depth. Every decision matters, from choosing where to scavenge to deciding whether to engage in combat or sneak past zombies. The game world is expansive and open-ended, allowing for emergent gameplay experiences that keep you coming back for more.

One of the standout features of Project Zomboid is its multiplayer mode. Surviving with friends (or strangers) adds a whole new dimension to the experience. Cooperation becomes essential, and the thrill of exploring together or defending a base as a team is unparalleled.

Another impressive aspect of Project Zomboid is its modding community. The game supports extensive modding, allowing players to customize and expand their gameplay experience in countless ways. This commitment to modding has kept the game fresh and engaging for years, with a dedicated community contributing new content regularly.

While Project Zomboid is still technically in Early Access, the level of polish and content is already impressive. The developers continue to release updates and improvements, addressing community feedback and refining the game further.

In summary, Project Zomboid is a must-play for anyone who loves survival games or the zombie apocalypse genre. It's a game that rewards strategic thinking, careful planning, and adaptability. Whether you're a lone survivor braving the undead alone or part of a group fighting to rebuild society, Project Zomboid offers an immersive and challenging experience that will keep you hooked for hours on end. If you haven't tried it yet, now is the perfect time to dive into this indie gem and experience the apocalypse like never before.

Creamy Survival Bliss: Project Zomboid Hits the Sweet Spot!"

Review:
When it comes to survival games, Project Zomboid doesn't just tick the boxes – it creams my creamsicle in the most delightful way possible! From the very first moment I stepped into its zombie-infested world, I knew I was in for an unforgettable ride.

What makes Project Zomboid stand out from the horde of survival titles is its commitment to realism. Every decision you make, every resource you scavenge, and every step you take matters in this unforgiving world. It's a constant battle for survival that keeps you on the edge of your seat, with adrenaline coursing through your veins.

But amidst the chaos and danger, there's a strange beauty to be found. The satisfaction of fortifying your safe haven against the undead horde, the thrill of exploring abandoned buildings for precious supplies, and the camaraderie of teaming up with fellow survivors – it all adds up to an experience that's as addictive as it is exhilarating.

And let me tell you, the depth of gameplay here is absolutely mind-blowing. Whether you're meticulously planning your next move or improvising in the heat of the moment, every playthrough offers new challenges and opportunities. It's a game that encourages creativity and ingenuity, rewarding those who dare to think outside the box.

Now, don't get me wrong – no game is without its flaws. But in the case of Project Zomboid, any occasional bugs or glitches are minor blemishes on an otherwise flawless experience. The developers have done an incredible job of squashing any undead bugs that may pop up, ensuring a smooth and immersive gameplay experience.

In conclusion, Project Zomboid isn't just a game – it's a creamy, dreamy journey through the apocalypse that satisfies my survival cravings in the best possible way. So if you're looking for a game that'll "cream your creamsicle" and then some, look no further. Grab your backpack, sharpen your axe, and dive headfirst into this undead masterpiece. You won't regret it.

Project Zomboid is a standout survival game that immerses you in a post-apocalyptic world overrun by the undead. Your mission is simple: survive. But don't be fooled by the simplicity – this game is anything but easy.

What sets Project Zomboid apart is its focus on realism. Every decision you make, from scavenging for supplies to fortifying your safehouse, carries weight. With death being permanent for the character you're playing, one wrong move could spell the end.

Crafting is key in this game, allowing you to create weapons and shelters to stay alive. The dynamic weather and day/night cycle keep you on your toes, forcing you to adapt your survival strategies.

The multiplayer aspect adds depth, whether you're teaming up with friends or competing for resources. While visually minimalist, the game's atmosphere draws you in, immersing you in the struggle to survive.

In short, Project Zomboid is a challenging and immersive survival experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Whether you're a seasoned survivor or new to the genre, this game promises endless opportunities for exploration and discovery in a world overrun by the undead.

161078836.review:
I bought this game for 13 euros, and I must say it's quite enjoyable. The gameplay and mechanics are well-crafted, featuring a realistic food system, water management, health concerns, and various other elements that immerse you in the game world. Graphics are not the main focus here; it's all about the gameplay.

Let's delve into the gameplay itself: Project Zomboid offers a unique experience. Set in Kentucky, the game starts with your character spawning in one of four towns. You have a wide array of traits, skills, and roles to choose from at the beginning.

Once spawned, your goal is to survive amidst hordes of zombies, managing resources and dealing with injuries. The concept is classic, but the execution is what stands out. You can engage in activities like cooking, mechanics, and more, adding depth to the gameplay. The game doesn't have a definitive end; it continues indefinitely until your character meets an unfortunate demise due to a mistake.

Pros:

-Realistic mechanics that add depth to the gameplay
-Expansive map with plenty of loot and suitable locations for bases
-Unique combat system and healing mechanics
-Features wildlife, including raccoons
-Advanced AI for zombies
-Impressive physics engine
-Every action you take can have consequences for your character's well-being
-Strong community support with numerous mods available to enhance the experience

Cons:

-Losing all skills upon death can be frustrating, especially after investing hours into the game
-The game is still in development after 11-12 years, which may raise concerns about its -completion
-Lack of NPC system (although there are mods available)
-Gameplay can become repetitive after extended play sessions
-Lack of a clear ending or resolution; some players may desire more closure or progression options

In conclusion, with only 15 hours of playtime (and approximately 50 hours overall, not counting time on Steam), I believe Project Zomboid is a fantastic game. However, potential buyers should consider their tolerance for frustration from sudden deaths or potential boredom over time before making a purchase.

160068927.review: Project Zomboid, hands down, is the ultimate zombie apocalypse experience for hardcore gamers. The game, crafted by The Indie Stone, throws you into a detailed and realistic survival world where every decision matters. The isometric view adds a strategic layer, making the whole experience intense and heart-pounding as you navigate through a world teeming with the undead. Micromanaging hunger, thirst, and mental well-being adds a gritty realism that hardcore gamers crave. The dynamic and changing world, coupled with retro-inspired graphics, creates a unique atmosphere that runs smoothly even on less powerful systems. Multiplayer takes the game to a whole new level, allowing you to team up with friends, build bases, and face the zombie horde together. Sure, there's a steep learning curve and the occasional bug, but if you're up for a no-nonsense, hardcore zombie survival challenge, Project Zomboid is the game for you. Get ready to unleash your inner survivalist and conquer the apocalypse like a true gaming pro!

159868357.review:
This game is brutal. Even if you go into sandbox mode and change up settings to make the game way more forgiving- such as by enabling easy cars, halving the zombie population, weakening the zombies, etc. You will still be faced with excruciating challenge. 

However, once you get the basics down and understand what you can do and what is possible- the best areas for what- how to approach certain events and otherwise, you will be able to deal with most situations this game throws at you.

The difficulty curve is immense, it starts off hard and drops in difficulty as you get better gear, only to ramp back up again when you've got a horde coming at you, or perhaps a helicopter flew by, and now everything in the mile radius is on you. 

The biggest thing is the unforgiving nature of PZ- you can spend hours upon hours working on a character and getting their skills up only to die and lose all of your progress. (This is tragic)

Don't let that dissuade you- keep pushing and moving, maybe even reduce the population and weaken the zombies even more. Once you know this games core mechanics, you can choose how difficult you want the game in all totality. 

This game is realistic- (somewhat)- You've got a whole bunch of things to look out for- whether that'd be your anxiety, hunger, temperature, or sickness- this game will throw everything a zombie apocalypse would have at you- in your mere human flesh. This, truly is, the story of how you die.

HOWEVER- the biggest problem with this game is middle to late game content. Eventually, you run out of things to do, you can expand and build up your base to whatever size you wish, learn recipes for electrical traps and whatnot- but eventually you will reach a phase in the game where you simply have nothing to worry about- you've got everything you could want in MASS abundance at your base, you've got enough rain collectors and farmland for you to not need to venture off anywhere, you collected every single car in the game, you've developed your base to become as great as it could be- and now your at a standstill of having nothing else to do- the challenge is gone, and this game loses its brutality... Just like real life.

However- I've heard about The Survivors that existed prior to my gameplay, and that will exist hopefully soon after this review- That will add enough middle game content to keep the player well occupied, especially since it is in one way or another, a narrative generator- Somewhat like Rimworld set in the zombie apocalypse. 

However, as for late game- I can only wish there was a quest system or even just a SUPER grindy-focused campaign that has an 'end'. It would make the late game just all the more bearable. I also believe there needs to be more incentive to leave base once its developed enough to be self-sustainable, something that isn't renewable and unfarmable, something you HAVE to go out for. Many would say that it'd lie in ammunition for weapons- but you could opt out of long range and go for melee and it'll work just fine enough to keep the zombies away from your base. Sure, we go out every once in a while for a supply run but it is of so little requirement that it just makes the game dry out into a stalemate of a game.

Overall, a wonderful survival game that lacks a few features to complete the experience. 
7.5/10

Project Zomboid (PZ) is probably one of my favourite games simply for the fact it is never the same thing twice.  It doesn't matter:
- If you make the same survivor each time
- If you use the same spawn point
- If you think you've got all the game skills you need on lock down

You can be the most mighty of players and you can still find yourself in hairy situations that keep you in survivor mode. Good luck and bad luck are still gonna getcha.

I wholeheartedly appreciate the work that has gone into the multiplayer process. I'm super excited for animals and npcs in the future (as I've been along with early access for a long time). The graphics can be toned down for weak machines (which I used to have personally) and the workshop is a wild west of potentials if you want to mod up. You can shift difficulties and so many aspects of a sandbox game to make it a chill time or a 27 Days later time.

The workshop mods I appreciate the most? New towns and places. I love exploring.
The pranks I love most as a server host? Changing shambling zombies to sprinters on days no one is expecting it. Your friends will scream when zombies come at them full tilt. Lets call it the "I guess you guys are too comfortable" days.

I've played 1046 hours so far at this moment of review and I'm going to keep stacking on those hours ongoing. Happy surviving!

159355701.review:
If you are reading this you have probably heard of and possibly seen project zomboid and are considering buying it yourself, after playing dozens of hours of this game I have gotten a firm grasp of the early game and a fair understanding of mid game play. here is what I know,

-Mechanics-
The mechanics in project zomboid are numerous and can sometimes come off as confusing to brand new players who may be going in blind, The tutorial provided is an excellent starting point for all new players (seriously, if you don't think you need it, yes you do.) it eases you into game play as the most you will get from this point on are ONE TIME POPUPS once these pop ups are closed THEY WILL NEVER BE OPENED AGAIN ON THAT WORLD and you will have to go into the trips menu to find them. doing this when fighting off a horde is not ideal when you REALLY need to know how to hot wire a car. (Personal Experience)

-combat
 flows well and their is a decent variety fo strategies to deal with varying zomboid herd sizes. 

-base building
while not a mechanic I personally use often I will say it gives you a great objective when trying to fix up a little house or if your building a small compound!

-resource management
One of the key aspects of the game that can either be Brain rot easy or insanely hard, It all depends on what you are doing in game!

-moodles
moodles are a hit or miss thing for me, after about 20 hours I began playing with a few mods that make my management a bit better and easier to keep up on, however I know several people who play without these mods and are able to play perfectly fine, You do you boo.

-Stats and skills
Sometimes gaining certain skills or stats can be REALLY tedious, but most of the time its actually quite easy to pull off long term. (I personally recommend Firefighter or burgler for new players as they have great starting for both stats and skills)

-The zomboids
Ah, The Zomboid. The coolest part of the game and what makes it a zombie survival game! Zomoid's can range in difficulty depending on what you do in the customization menu but the best way to describe them is this.
>Walkers
Walkers are the slowest possible zomboid in the vanilla game and are very similar too walking dead zombies
>shamblers
Shamblers are slightly stronger and faster then the walkers and are easily underestimated as you may be able to outpace them but they are relentless in that they will follow you for quite some time. 
>Sprinters
sprinters are by far the "scariest zomboid" as they are the strongest zomboid and will quite literally sprint at you the moment you are spotted, even the most seasoned veterans of the game find trouble in handling even one of these things. 

Project Zomboid is by far my favorite survival game and with a price point of just 10 dollars and a VERY dedicated development team and fleshed out modding scene you will always find a reason to come back to project zomboid!

I bought it end of last year as I was looking to scratch the Zombie Apocalypse Survival itch and this game checked all of the boxes on paper. Cut to Jan. of this year when I thought, maybe I just need to give it more time, bought, downloaded and still hated it, went to refund again, but last minute for some reason I pulled that request and gave it one last try. As you can see from my playtime, I fell in love. tbh this is probably the best game I've ever played, to the extend that if I was to make a game this would probably be it. I've never really been a fan of players saying "give the game time it gets better" but I will say with this game, if the controls bother you, or specific aspects feel off, etc, give it time it really does get better and I actually now think the controls are pretty damn good. There is literally nothing IMHO out there like this, its truly a gem and I cant recommend it enough. I'd close with, in my 30 some odd years of gaming, I never really thought I'd have a "forever" game as some people do, but this is probably my "forever" game.

158047705.review:
I'll start by saying that I am not a fan of survival games. I'm also very wary of early access. Project Zomboid broke the mold in both cases.

Most survival games that I've played, even ones with consistent elements of danger, have felt like chore simulators. Project Zomboid's implementation of survival mechanics is something else entirely, however. The slow shamblers of Romero films, which Zomboid's default settings are based on, are the ultimate persistence hunters. Here, the survival aspects enhance this. They aren't just a chore. They're what makes the game worth coming back to.

The game has an incredible number of customization options, and that's before taking user created mods into consideration. 

It's also incredibly in depth. Let me give you an example:
My current character is living out of his car - The back seats are filled with canned food, ammunition for his guns, books on survival basics and more. Last night he pulled into what I thought was a middle of nowhere gas station on the back roads of Kentucky. It was getting late, he needed to refill his water bottles, refuel his car, and maybe find something to eat in the gas station before finding somewhere to get some sleep. There was one or two zombies lurking outside the station, but - no biggie, I figured he'd just quickly pop them with his rifle and be on his way. Shouldn't be too many out there.

If I'd driven just a little bit further down the road, I'd have seen the larger parking lot of a nearby diner, the street that turned into a tightly packed cul-de-sac. Two shots rang out, the gas station's pumps began to hum to life as he started refueling his car... And a horde lurched around the fence into view. He hopped in his car and sped off, dead limbs catching in the wheel well and nearly grinding them to a halt. One of the headlights went out from the impact, the other had a dead bulb from before he ever found the car. The sun was setting, it was getting dark, and speeding off down the road he slammed into a tree.

The engine won't turn over now, his wrist is broken - so even if he's a crack shot with a rifle it won't be much use for him. He's got one bottle of water left, and nothing he might need to start repairing his engine. It's going to be a long walk back to town in the morning, a town I know now is swarming with zombies, and just in the hopes of finding some basic supplies alongside, hopefully, a wrench, a book on mechanics, and maybe a vhs tape that will cover the basics of car repair.

There are other survival games out there. I've tried a lot of them, even if survival games aren't my bag - because I've been looking for the authentic zombie apocalypse experience. None of them come close to the kind of considerations and decision making that come up in Project Zomboid.
Is it worth 20$? Definitely. Honestly, even in early access I think it's already well worth more.

157587114.review:
Despite how simple the game looks, you'll be hard pressed to find a better zombie-survival game. There's a lot built into the game already, with far more variability coming in the future. The game keeps track of your calorie intake as well as your protein intake for keeping track of your weight and your ability to build muscle respectively.

The game also keeps track of your clothing and the protection and insulation it's providing each part of your character's body. Some clothing is more protective than others. Some clothing is better insulated than others. You can even use a needle and thread to repair holes or add protective patches to your clothing. The protection stat can literally prevent you from being bitten or scratched by zombies when they do land an attack on you, which can lead to infections and death. Even zombification, where your character will continue to roam that world file as a zombie.

Insulation determines how well your clothing traps heat to keep your character warm. In the hotter months, more protection is always good, but can and will lead to you overheating and increasing how much water you need to drink. In the colder/rainier months, you want to bundle up with good insulation and try your best to stay indoors while it's raining/snowing.

Running around outside during storms, specifically getting really wet on a windy day, can lead to your character catching a cold. This will make you cough and sneeze uncontrollably unless you're carrying a handkerchief. Which merely muffles the sounds when they're made. Coughing/Sneezing will attract zombies nearby.

You can fully build your own bases all around the map. You can get generators, which run on gasoline, in many garages and other places. Place one OUTSIDE of your base and fuel it up to provide your base with power. You can also build barrels for catching rain, which can be used to provide water to sinks or clothes washers. If you have a washing machine, you'll also need to have electricity running to operate it. You could even throw in a clothes dryer to mostly automate your laundry-cleaning duties.

With your own base, you could even try farming and planting some of the seeds that you can find scattered around the map in various places. That's assuming you want to settle down and work out of a base. Instead, you can find a nice car/truck/van and try to look inside or around the vehicle for a key. With the right tools and skill level, or the Burglar class selected at character creation, you can hotwire a car and start it that way.

Don't forget that cars still need fuel though. So you should plan on siphoning gas out of any other vehicles in the area just to top up for exploring. Eventually, you're going to want to find one of the several gas stations scattered around the map. Once the electricity goes out, you'll need to place a generator at the gas station to power the gas pumps.

With a decent vehicle that isn't too damaged, you're ready to start venturing outside of the town you started in. Most of it's wilderness, but there are a lot of other towns and small settlements as well. Your best bet is to pick a road and stick to it until you find something. Don't forget to make use of any maps you find as well. They can often point the way to survivor caches with food and weapons.

I could actually type out several more large paragraphs explaining mechanics I haven't even touched on, but this should be enough to convince anyone who's interested in what the game has to offer. There's plenty more to discover in the game and the next few builds will be expanding on pretty much all of what I've mentioned already. Not to mention adding entirely new things into the game like NPCs with their own A.I. controlling them. They'll be completely overhauling the class systems and making them play more of a part during mid to late game while also adding in a new crafting system revolving around some of those classes.

Needless to say, the game is amazing and it's only ever improving. If anything I said interested you, definitely give the game a shot. You won't be disappointed.

161751733.review:
Let's begin with the cons:
* The game is in development for MORE THAN A DECADE and it won't release anytime soon.
* The controls are clunky and many QoL features are missing.
* It's brutal. A single scratch from a zombie might kill you and a single bite certainly will.

Other things that some people might not like:
* There is no goal other than "survive". There is no ending other than death. This is a game about the journey, not the destination.
* This game is meant to be played with mods. Don't get me wrong, the vanilla experience is still worth it but it's nowhere near of what you can get with a hundred of mods.

If that did not scare you then just buy it. The game is awesome and easily one of the best that I ever played. It has a huge map (google it now), lots of gameplay mechanics, vehicles, tons of loot, crafting, movable furniture, the list goes on and on. Better yet, the game feels very differently, depending on whether you are playing it solo, in co-op, or on a public server. In single player it is a lonely, depressing experience. You are the only one alive, the civilization is collapsing, howling wind and dead bodies are your only company. The game is the same in multiplayer but if you are not alone, your home base will feel more cozy than ever, very much like a true home. Enough of this sentimental nonsense, go buy it immediately.

159349677.review:
You run in 2 directions throughout your playtime in Project Zomboid: you run towards your inevitable death, and then you run back to where you died to get your stuff back (Sometimes these directions are the same). There is no ultimate goal to surviving this apocalypse. You will not collect 3 magic stones to undo the curse; you will not repair the Omega MacGuffin to purify Kentucky of the undead. You will rip into every truckstop diner, college dormitory, and washroom wastebin looking for a roll of scotch tape or a AA battery. And unless you've memorized the street map of 1994 Kentucky, you will find yourself wandering through empty, content-free farmers' fields for 40 minutes at a time a little TOO often.

I can't admonish Project Zomboid for its directionlessness, because its systems are so dense. You can get a map, but you have to find it. You have to pull the map out and look at it. You can take notes on it, but only in the colours of writing utensils you've looted, and you can erase the notes, but only if they're in pencil - and you have an eraser. Generally, Zomboid boldly refuses to be "a game" in its commitment to a realistic simulation, however it seems to "cheat" this philosophy by gamifying the rarity of common real-world items like sledges and needles because they're "good".

After 10+ years in "early access" - I think "ongoing development" is probably a more serious term at this point - Zomboid is not a very good game, but it's an awfully good something.

158760026.review:
Pretty solid game deserving of its favourable reviews, even as someone who had to painstakingly play this without a mouse.

Another review down here noted that instead of acting as some sort of enhanced, superpowered entity, you are playing as a regular individual who is stressed-out, panicking, hungry, and tired. You get various advantages to choose from, which must be offset by disadvantages, so that your character ends up being thoroughly balanced. The game mechanics itself may seem simple at first, with the process of killing a zombie not requiring much skill, but there is a fair bit of survival instinct that must be employed if you wish to avoid alerting all the zombies in the area and being quickly overwhelmed.

The survival portion is huge and forces you to stay constantly aware of multiple factors at a time. Breaking into a window can result in broken glass that cuts you, and if that cut goes untreated, can become infected and develop into something much more dangerous. Food can replenish your hunger but stale food can adversely affect your happiness levels. Failing to clean up blood after killing zombies can attract more zombies and result in a horde, and so on. Ultimately, this game is worth the shot as it isn't particularly pricey and its multifaceted nature can keep you up for long periods, especially when playing with friends.

[h1]Survival Masterpiece: Project Zomboid[/h1]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
[b]Project Zomboid[/b] is an unparalleled survival experience that thrusts players into a post-apocalyptic world overrun by the undead. Developed by Indie Stone, this game offers an immersive and unforgiving journey through the remnants of society.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
[b]Project Zomboid[/b] excels in its gameplay mechanics, offering a unique blend of survival, sandbox, and RPG elements. The game challenges players to scavenge for resources, build shelter, and fend off hordes of zombies while managing their character's health, hunger, and sanity. The open-world nature of the game allows for limitless exploration and creative freedom, ensuring each playthrough is a fresh and engaging experience.

[h2]Graphics and Sound[/h2]
While the graphics may not be cutting-edge, the minimalist art style of [b]Project Zomboid[/b] effectively conveys the grim atmosphere of a world in ruins. The sound design further enhances the immersive experience, with haunting ambient noises and the ominous moans of approaching zombies keeping players on edge at all times.

[h2]Community and Modding[/h2]
One of the standout features of [b]Project Zomboid[/b] is its dedicated community and robust modding support. With a thriving community of players and an active modding scene, the game offers endless opportunities for customization and player-created content, ensuring that the fun never ends.

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
[b]Project Zomboid[/b] stands as a testament to the potential of indie gaming, offering a deeply satisfying and immersive survival experience. With its rich gameplay mechanics, atmospheric world, and vibrant community, this game is a must-play for any fan of the survival genre. Strap in, stock up, and prepare to fight for your life in the zombie-infested world of [b]Project Zomboid[/b].

The development for PZ has been a long grind, but a steady one. The game has come leaps and bounds and is easily the best zombie survival sim out there. The detail and thought put into this game is incredible and the fact that it has not been abandoned after so many years proves (to me) that the devs really just want a perfect game on full release. It has public/private multiplayer, split screen, mod support, and they listen to the community fairly well. As slow as it has come along it beats the feeling of grand promise followed by the swift inability to deliver anything and have the devs just abandon the project..

On the downsides PZ can feel empty and a bit repetitive after 100+ hours or so, or getting into the late game on a character. If it was not for mods or multiplayer that time could very easily be less in its current state. That being said it really depends on your RP experience/interest and if you are the type who likes to set goals for yourself in a game. It is always a game you will come back to and easily worth the money for the enjoyment you will get out of it. (Even if you arent any god at the game) There is just nothing else quite like it out there. On final release with animals, npcs, maybe quests, will definitely be an epic adventure.

I would buy it again.

This game has an unforgiving difficulty, no saves (except to stop playing and then continue), and permadeath.
This means that it's a very fustrating game and very hard for novices.
Then why everyone loves that game? Because it's a good game. It's complex, it's interesting, there's lots of places to explore, has various mechanics and you can specialice on several trades.
And also, there's the multiplayer. In multiplayer the experience is even better, if you play with people you know, and you group to survive together.
The modding community is big and very productive, and it's deeply embraced by the developers (in the coming 42 version you'll be able to download and install mods directly from inside the game).

If you tried this game and found it too hard, try this: create a new game and just pick the first weapon you can find and start killing zombies. Don't do anything else. Don't fear being bitten or killed. When dead, rinse and repeat. When you're confortable dealing with a small horde (10 to 15 zombies), then you can start a proper game. The rest of stuff you must learn to play won't kill you nor your drive to keep playing. So just learn to manage yourself on a horde, and you'll start really enjoying the game.

157178562.review:
If you're seeking an unparalleled and immersive zombie apocalypse survival experience, look no further than Project Zomboid. As a seasoned survivor myself, I wholeheartedly recommend this open-world, top-down view game that will challenge your survival instincts and strategic thinking in the face of a relentless undead horde. 
Project Zomboid excels in providing a realistic survival simulation. You'll need to manage hunger, thirst, fatigue, and various other needs. The game's attention to detail adds depth to the survival experience, making every decision crucial to your character's well-being. 
The vast, open-world map of Project Zomboid offers a multitude of environments to explore. From urban centers to rural areas, each location presents unique challenges and opportunities. The dynamic weather system and day-night cycle add an extra layer of realism to your survival journey. 
Scavenging for resources is a constant necessity, and the game allows you to find, collect, and craft a wide variety of items. From makeshift weapons to fortifications for your safehouse, every resource has a purpose, and your ability to adapt and utilize what you find will be crucial to your survival. 
The zombies in Project Zomboid are not mere cannon fodder; they are intelligent, and their numbers can quickly overwhelm the unprepared. Whether you choose to sneak past them or confront them head-on, every encounter is a tense and strategic affair. 
As you survive longer, your character will gain experience and skills. The progression system is rewarding and adds an RPG element to the game. Customize your character's abilities to suit your preferred playstyle, but remember, death is permanent – making each decision impactful. 
For those who prefer surviving with friends, Project Zomboid offers a multiplayer co-op mode. Team up with others to face the challenges of the apocalypse together, sharing resources, strategies, and the thrill of survival.
Project zomboid features a modding option, allowing players to create their own experiences custom tailored through selections of countless content. Mod creators have added everything from weapons to cars to whole map expansions to the workshop. With this wide selection, it is left entirely up to the player when it comes to creating a unique experience.
The developers of Project Zomboid have consistently supported the game with updates and new content. The active development ensures that the game stays fresh, with ongoing improvements and additions to enhance the overall gaming experience. 
In conclusion, Project Zomboid is not just a game; it's a survival odyssey that will test your wit, resilience, and adaptability. Whether you're a lone wolf or a cooperative survivor, the challenges of this zombie-infested world await you. Strap in, be prepared, and may your survival instincts guide you through the harrowing landscapes of Project Zomboid.

Firstly id like to say that this game went above and beyond my expectations.
It is highly immersive, has a very real and compelling zombie narrative which can be further improved with mods of course that not only change the way the game can be played but it has a especially given the game a fresh take with the quality of life content it provides.

Secondly it is a super hardcore experience even if sandbox settings are tweaked to be easier, Because of the perma-Death you feel like every action has consequences like in real life.
even after my 200 plus hours ive still been learning new things/mechanics in the game.
I have died many times but recently my play styles have changed and id have to say that the base building is satisfying.
Literally any item can be placed in the world that is picked up to make bases etc really feel alive and at home for your character.

Thirdly Death in the game is only the beginning......For example you can pick up from where you left off as a new character with the draw back being that you lose all skills acquired from your previous character.
If you liked to be highly immersed in a Zombie apocalypse then this is the game for you.
If you want to hate life and yourself tweak settings in sand box to give the desired out come but with that said i recommend playing the game first in its intended way so you can truly appreciate the progression of your character and most of all yourself as the player.

Lastly its like you are the director of a movie and your character is the protagonist thats destined to die, even from over confidents or from becoming to complacent.
i could go on and on about the pros and cons but as it stands the many pros of this game is overpowering in comparison to the cons so i cant recommend this game enough.
with the Multiplayer its another story though, id definitely play with some friends or join the many communities available.

158082401.review:
I've survived more than a year on a character and I can assure you there is more than enough food on the map to live 10 years without farming, fishing or trapping. You'll eventually die to nonsense even if you're a good player, such as doors on a car not shutting but there is no animation to warn you *shakes fist at sky*.

So ultimately the game is a test of how long you can be alone. While there is multiplayer, that format has issues which can be just as challenging to get over as the loneliness in single player such as desync (screen will turn black and freeze until things load) and zombie count limitations.

When you decide to buy or not buy this game, completely ignore any promises from the developers on what is coming "soon." There is no soon, as they have decided to take as long as they want to develop their game. That is their prerogative, but as a consumer you should be informed on what that means. They have been promising animals and npcs for 10 years. TEN YEARS. The title of the game is "project" for a reason and it is never going to leave early access. NEVER. I've lost confidence in the studio's ability to ever be able to overhaul their existing code (imagine working on the same code for over a decade and NOT having it become spaghetti). Just on the basis that every UI in the game is different it should be obvious to everyone they don't have a solid code base.

So if you want to challenge yourself for a few hundred hours solo or forever in modded multiplayer, know that these have their limitations and there is no update coming from the developers in a realistic time period to address those issues. Play the game for what it is today with its faults, or don't. Just don't fall for the upcoming content unless you plan on watching your grandchildren play some day from a rocking chair.

160439284.review:
Touted positively by many, but a massive unexpected letdown.

Rating: 3/10

I had fairly high hopes for Project Zomboid after hearing nothing but praises from its community; most, if not all of them, mentioned the freedom and uniqueness of gameplay this zombie survival game delivers. However, after trying very hard to get into the game and trying to like it, I discovered it just has too many rough edges that hinder enjoyment.

First of all, the balancing of the game is all over the place. Never have I played a zombie game or a zombie survival game where the zombies absolutely annoy the hell out of me. The zombies have a vision range of a NASA telescope and hearing of a mutant X-men. It isn't the kind of enjoyable challenge but more a "stack all the unbalanced odds against you" type of frustrating challenge that leaves you wanting to play a better zombie survival experience. The "combat" is extremely one-sided and drags out too long.

The game has multiple issues with bugs and performance problems as well. You'd expect that the developers, after leaving this game in early access for almost a few years now, would have ironed out most of the things and be soon to be released in full. But some segments of the game seem like they were designed in the alpha stages of the game. In addition, the various frame drops in a game that has sprite graphics are simply unacceptable.

The UI has got to be one of the worst I have ever experienced in a game. Clunky, unintuitive, and counterproductive. Managing inventory, gear, and resources is an absolute chore. The UI is so clunky that you may get lost in it; it takes up the whole screen and has barely any transparency, so you may unknowingly get bitten by a zombie just because the UI is taking up half the screen and blocking your field of view.

Overall, a massive letdown. I have a high tolerance for janky games, but never have I felt I wasted money more on a video game product than Project Zomboid.

159942581.review:
For new players, Project Zomboid is a daunting and often terrifying game. This is to the games credit as it has been a long time since a game made me tense. It has a dedicated modding community and the game functions very well. Things to consider: the controls take some getting used to and it highly recommended you start with highlighted targeting as you learn the game. Also, don't get too attached to anything as death is permanent (short of backup saves) and you will be punished for early mistakes. Heavily punished.

About the settings: it is recommended that you lower the zombie count early on and slowly increase the difficulty as you progress. If you start off too hard, the game will be very frustrating. Sometimes it will feel like it's the game's fault, but that's rarely the case. More often the not, the game is working as intended and it was you, the player, who was either too confident or careless. 

Graphically... it's decent. The style works well for the game, but I think it could benefit from a rotating camera. I

Loot: There's a lot of it. It can be frustrating to deal with the loot since there is such a variety of it and you won't know what the use is until later. Likely after abandoning it in some container you can't remember. 

Solid 8/10. Highly recommended for those who want a "realistic" zombie survival simulator. You are not some boss character; you're just a regular person. Keep that in mind and you'll last longer.

161580867.review:
I love survival games and Project Zomboid does so much right. There is a lot of attention to detail and realism. 
I don't recommend this game for anyone just trying to have fun. This is not a casual fun game.
This game is extremely frustrating and there is still a lot of work to be done to make this a truly enjoyable experience. \
Working for hours and hours, possibly even days to that ONE zombie that bit you on some legit BS? It just makes me want to uninstall. 
When you get bitten for something as dumb as how clunky it is for your character to do certain actions or even turn?
The game is supposed to be centered around dying. On one hand, alright sure. Survive as long as I can? Cool.
In actual practice? Not fun. That feels like a rogue-like element that is entirely out of place. Am I supposed to die or am I supposed to live? 
The game really makes it so you have to adjust the settings to fit your place style. That can be really cool for some people. Personally, I don't feel like I should HAVE to change the settings of a game to make it enjoyable. 

TLDR; if you have the patience and you're specifically looking for a challenge, or if you're okay with needing to change a whole slew of settings to have fun, then pick it up.

159582694.review:
I keep trying to like this game so hard. I keep coming back to it and can't play more than 45 min or so at a clip. It's an exercise in tedium. It tries to be ultra realistic which I get but it ends up being a contrived experience and tedious to do things that should be easier.  If I'm standing next to sink and I need to wash bandages why does it use my water bottle?? Now I have to refill my water bottle. That's just one example. 
 
Combat is still terrible. Trying to control the survivor is jank and awkward. How did they not figure this out by now? You bleed so easy when you get hit and you bleed out so fast. Bandages are easy enough to make but you'll be changing them at least once and it's more micromanagement. God forbid you even find bandages. You'll be making them from other objects like clothing.  

Hunger? Every fucking 5 min of gameplay my character is hungry and trying to eat anything is a process. Where are the can openers?? Have fun finding one. Meanwhile, in reality every kitchen in the world has at least one but no, not your kitchen. In fact, you own nothing but 6 cans of food (with no can opener??), one tissue, and the clothing on your back. You neighbor? Owns a total of 4 items. Where did everyone's tools go?? Zombies eat tools, most people don't realize that. Shouldn't there be more cars around? Did people leave town or turn into zombies?? You have to choose one or the other. What is the narrative in this game? It's been 10 years of "early access". Bro, add some sort of narrative already.  

Carry weight?? With a backpack I get 12.5 pounds. I can carry like 6 cans of food and some clothing. Have fun looting and running back and forth back and forth back and forth. 

Skills?? Have fun grinding those out while you die way too easily. What a dumb game balance. 

My last attempt was on the "Build" difficulty setting, which was suppose to be relaxed and focused on building and crafting. Well, I started with zero tools, both neighbors had zero tools, and there were no crafting materials other than furniture to be disassembled. I still had to fight a bunch of zombies near my house and on the second day my house had like 7 zombies waiting out back. Keeping in mind I found zero weapons. Can't I rip a leg off a table?  Who the fuck designs this shit? I get so angry when my time and energy is wasted like this.  

I'm writing this to hopefully save someone time although I'm sure everyone has played this game by now if you like the genre.

19429632.review:
I've lived entire lives in this game.  Braved bitter winters.  Sorted and labeled crates of canned food, wondering how long it would last me.  Tended crops and cursed the misfortune of plant disease.  Fractured my leg and holed up in the corner of some dilapidated warehouse dying of thirst since I lacked the speed to get home safely.  I've lived a thousand lives and felt the touch of death so many times, now I'm only surprised when it doesn't come swiftly.

What I've learned is that death isn't failure, no, it's a sweet release.  Make no mistake, I've survived for a long time, built impregnable safehouses with self-sustaining crops, high above where any zombie could reach.  But that is simply a different kind of death, death in the form of boredom, but it is a death all the same.  It makes sense though, doesn't it?  You are the last person on Earth, the world is filled with endless zombies, there is no happy ending to all of this.

But the point isn't to survive, the point is to create your own tale, make a snapshot of experiences that are memorable.  This game is really just an analogy for life and death, compressed into a few hours at a time, and how you choose to spend your time reflects on your personality.  How will you keep death at bay?  Will you build walls, will you hide, will you run as far away as you can, or will you pick up an axe and try to fight it?  It doesn't matter, death will find you in the end, but it will be a hell of a journey.

106218675.review:
It's late night. On top of my exhaustion, I'm blinded by the absence of light. But I can't stop now.

I've been walking for almost an entire day - although in my current state, this feels more like an eternity. My weary footsteps echo through the desolate, darkly moonlit roads. My previous safehouse was overwhelmed by a straggling horde the day before. I ran, only with a small bugout bag I could salvage while I drowned in desperation and fear.

Finally, I stumble upon a new city, utterly fatigued, parched, and famished. Lost in the suffocating darkness, I desperately search for refuge, until my bleary eyes catch sight of a looming dark silhouette - a mansion, cloaked by the deepest shadow of the night.

Feeling the walls in the dark, I am blessed with luck. This feels like an utter disrespect to the oppressive darkness around me. I managed to grasp the doorknob on my first attempt - and it is unlocked. Fumbling blindly, I confirm that every entry point on the ground floor remains sealed shut. Denying myself of solace, fearful of prying eyes or ears, I determine that my only sanctuary lies on the mansion's upper floor.

I enter the suite, seeking shelter behind a fortress of barricaded doors and windows - the house's entrance, the bedroom's threshold, and ultimately, the final barrier of the bathroom door. Within those confines, I hope for the slightest reminiscence of peace, a fleeting moment of respite from the encroaching chaos outside. I pray that all these barriers that confine me within are enough for me to wake up from my slumber and muster the remaining of my dwindling vigor, in the chance that my new sanctuary is breached by the looming.

With every ounce of strength left in my battered, punished body, I hasten towards my coveted sanctuary, yearning for a sip of the last water drops from the city water supply and eating the remains of my canned dog food.

As I push open the bathroom door, the last portal to my salvation, fate unveils its malevolent mockery against me. I am not the only one who sought refuge within these walls. Another soul had the same idea before, sealing both our fates. Long ago, someone met their demise in this very room. Now, their lifeless corpse stands motionless, a grim sentinel guarding this bathroom. A puppet of chance, devoid of purpose, waiting for an unsuspecting prey - a perfectly set trap, just like a mousetrap anticipates its unwitting mouse.

I swing the door open, a gateway to either salvation or damnation. But in my exhausted state, my famished and sleepless body is unable to react swiftly enough. The reanimated corpse lunges at me, its rotten fangs sinking deep into my jugular.

105581217.review:
Alright, its time for the review. What is Project Zomboid? Is it a mix of Runescape and the Sims with a dash of zombie apocalypse?  Is it Day Z mixed with Stardew Valley where every neighbor is trying to marry their teeth into your jugular? I'm glad to report that its all of these things. With the inclusion of Project Zomboid's most recent Build 41.60 Experimental Multiplayer update, the game has taken the formula, and cranked it up to 11. 11,000. I have spent 1430 hours in Singleplayer, visiting each spot in this massive recreation of KY, learning, dying, and repeating, each time coming closer to the question the devs originally sought to answer, "Would you survive in a zombie apocalypse?" The answer turns out to be a resounding no. Every run cut short by careless mistakes, overconfidence, and lack of preparation. This games mechanics run deep, and if you adopt the mindset of "can I do this in real life?" You'll begin to do well in KY's abusive apocalypse landscape. Lets look at some of my favorite aspects:

- Sandbox settings.
You can alter every facet of the game world, from the day you start on (full 365 days a year to choose from, 4 seasons), the type of zombies and how many of them you want in your nightmare scenario, how much loot spawns, the chance the house you're looting is locked, if it has a house alarm, if it is a special loot house. It's all here and what I mentioned isn't even a fraction of the settings you can change. 

-Kentucky.
The map in this game is based loosely on the real world locations of various towns and cities of Kentucky. The games map has never felt this complete with 41.60. Louisville has been inserted into the world and boy, is it MASSIVE. Louisville truly feels like endgame content, as my group of 5 fought their way into the exclusion zone in the middle of a thunderstorm, guns blazing and only half of us made it into the center of the city and we lost our supplies to the horde. Every run feels fresh because of the versatility of the map. You can plan, build, farm, craft, camp, fish, forage, cook, become a car mechanic, Rambo your way down Muldraugh's strip, and create your ultimate scenario no matter where you end up. 

-Mods
Speaking with some mod developers and first hand creating my own mod with the help of the community, I can say that making mods in this game is fairly easy. Not to say that making a complicated mod is easy, and you can see with Autotsars mods, KI5's, iBrRus, Blackbeard, Azakaela and many other creators I haven't mentioned, are a staple to the community and Project Zomboid would not be the same without them. The list of content creators for this game is large and I expect to only increase as this game becomes more popular. Seriously, play this game vanilla, then try out some mods to add to the immersion of the game, you won't regret it.

-MULTIPLAYER
Finally. The big one. The multiplayer of Project Zomboid is not necessarily new, but it is a new inclusion of build 41.60. If you haven't enrolled in Build 41 already, then we are not playing the same game. The features this build brings far outweigh any reason to play the stable branch anymore. I played 12 hours of MP recently and DAMN. Just DAMN. Our first group of 12 tore through West Point, created a base on the outskirts of town, prepped for a journey to Louisville, and got slaughtered in Valley Station. We raided hardware stores, supermarkets, bookstores, shooting ranges, and car lots. Making the final push to greatness is without a doubt, far more enjoyable with friends. Hell, I never even met my group before we started, but we all became friends by the end of our survival. Most mods work with MP and while PvP and a few desync issues need to be ironed out, the potential Multiplayer brings to the game and its roleplaying implications will be quintessential to the success of itself in the coming years.

-Cons
+ Here is where I lay out some of the problems I have with the game. But if you have already seen how many hours I've played, you know this list is short enough. The development progress in this game is slow. The team behind it is small, but growing every year. The devs truly care, but they also do not care to release content before they think it is ready. That means waiting months for updates, and often a year for bigger updates. Luckily, the dev team has been transparent about the development with the community and there's a biweekly newsletter that lets everyone know what they're up to. If you want constant updates that bring fresh content to the game every week, this game may not be for you. If you like watching a game bloom from inception and grow into something special, this game is right up your alley. In the meantime, the community has mods for your every whim, so it's never been a huge issue for me. It's modding scene is beginning to rival Skyrim's or Minecraft's. 

+ The bugs in this game have been consistent for a while. While every update seems to squash a few dozen, a handful pop up from time to time, including zombies that flip on the ground, lag when driving fast vehicles and audio related bugs, missing or broken textures. Nothing that has ever been game breaking, but unfortunately, were immersion breaking. The devs have trackers and generally respond well to issues the community has, but again, you may have to wait a while until your specific issue may get fixed. 

+Vanilla content/Feature creep. When comparing my vanilla games to my modded games, the modded games always are superior. Some mods I can't imagine playing without now. The devs have done a great job setting up the foundation of the game, it now just needs some polish in some areas. Vanilla guns need more variety. The selection is weak and pistols, shotguns, and rifles are all fine in the beginning, but can become a detriment when facing hordes in the late game. The game does not include enough full auto weapons to handle these scenarios efficiently, but mods once again solve this issue. Throwing grenades and molotovs in this game is also absolute trash. These systems haven't been touched in ages, and with more content to soon follow, one wonders if the devs will ever revisit these sections again... Blacksmithing is mentioned in the game files, but has not been implemented yet. Car armor has yet to be implemented as well, and all of these things I'm mentioning ask the question, have the devs extended too far? I guess we will find out.

+Hardware specs. As the game begins to mature and add more features, lower spec machines are being left behind. You may begin to experience lag if you fall below the recommended specs and it doesn't look like that trend will change anytime soon. There are enough options to keep the FPS high, but I feel soon that wont be enough. If you are lower spec, I would try out the free demo in the Steam store to figure out if this game is right for you.

Final thoughts/ TL:DR:
If you didn't read any of that, then you don't need me to convince you. Buy this game. Its 14.99. That's the price of a craft beer 6 pack. This is the best RPG I have EVER played and my most played game time. What are you waiting for?

Easily the best survival game I've played.
Easily the best zombie game I've played.

However, this zombie survival game doesn't play so easily.
It's rough, it's tough, it's punishing, but it's rewarding. There are plateaus, not skill curves. 

Getting your first laceration from climbing through a broken window. Stomping a zombies head 10 times and wondering why it won't die because you're exhausted. Finding your first gun and realising at 0 skill it's really just a loud trumpet. Leaving something in the oven too long and causing a house fire. Accidentally pressing Q and getting your freshly done-up base surrounded. It's all part of the tried and true "learn from your mistakes" style of gameplay. 

Before long, you start to get comfortable with the threat of the zombies, and begin to experiment. "Ah," you think, "I can continually lure them through this window or over a fence! And they always trip!" And you feel so smart after killing 4 zombies in a row this way, until the 5th and 6th one both do a lunge and teach you a lesson. In the next life, you add fire to the mix - constantly kiting the horde around a single flame, feeling once again so smug about your genius brain, until you find yourself surrounded by the flames. 

Next time, you score yourself a car, and find out how devastating they are to the zoombinis. "Tally-ho!" you yell as you continually joust zombie hordes down the main streets, loud engine drawing more and more to the slaughter. You run down a few dozen more, maybe even learning of the "whirlwind" tactic as you drive around. But then the world goes quiet, and your car begins to silently coast, too slow to run down the horde that you were planning on. They come. They surround. They devour. "Damn". Another lesson in mortality. But you've learned. A car is a tool. Noise is a tool. Fire is a tool. And you are the Tool Man, with the world as your workshop. Blaze down the highways with your siren, lure the decaying ones to the purging flame, and cry as you accidentally run the car into a pole and break your neck, surrounded by the horde once again.

This is how you died.

first game in a year:

- me and a friend meet up near muldraugh, when I get there he tells me he's got attacked, he's wounded.
